all_paragraphs: Natural language processing (NLP) as a field has seen unprecedented growth (especially in the past 2 years due to the publication of BERT). And while much research is focused on tasks with huge implications (e.g., question-answering, text summarization), we should always remember that there are some fun applications of natural language processing research as well. For example, generating puns.

Let’s delve into a recent paper by He et al. that proposes a pretty-strong model for pun generation. P.S. if you just want to see some of the puns that the model ended up generating, I’ve included the puns that the authors give at the end of the post.

The Dataset. First thing’s first. Like any deep learning problem, generating puns obviously requires a not-small dataset. Now, personally I wouldn’t have even thought that a dataset of puns exists. Regardless, the authors found a good collection of puns: the pun dataset from the 2017 SemEval task, which contains 1,099 different puns. Although this is on the small side of datasets, it’s enough to get an acceptably-performing model trained.
Yesterday I swallowed some food coloring. The doctor says I’m OK, but I feel like I dyed a little inside. (“dyed” vs “died”)

How to generate a pun. So for this task, the authors have decided to focus on homophone puns (example given above). In homophone puns, the goal is to replace a pun word (in this case “died”) with an alternative word (“dyed”) which has the same pronunciation but a different meaning. To generate these puns, the authors proposed 3 main steps:
Here’s the example walkthrough of these steps that the authors give:

So in this example, Step 1 would be to find a sentence with the word “hair” in it. The model identifies the sentence “the man stopped to get a hair cut.” Next, the original pun word (“hair”) is replaced with a homophone (“hare”), yielding the updated sentence “the man stopped to get a hare cut.” But this doesn’t make sense yet, so in comes step 3. The topic is inserted by changing “man” to “greyhound” and giving us the completed pun:
“The greyhound stopped to get a hare cut.”’

And the results? To see how punny their model was, the authors called in Mechanical Turk workers. For 150 different pun pairs (one from a human and one from their model), five workers per pun were asked to rate the puns on three aspects:

Turns out that their model is pretty okay — the model outperformed humans on the funniness aspect for 10.7% of puns and the grammar aspect on 8% of puns. Considering that generating puns is a pretty hard task, I’m actually quite impressed that a computer can generate even one pun better than a human, much less ten percent. But anyways, let’s see where the model missed points.

Dang it, the model messed up the pun! So based on the authors’ pie chart of the errors that the model made, it looks like a good chunk of errors that the model was making came from picking a bad pun word or from not being able to pick a relevant topic word to provide context for the pun. Given that these are pretty difficult issues (ask me to come up with a pun on the spot, and I would probably be strugglin’), it makes sense to me that the model would have trouble with them.

Conclusion. So the authors did a great job presenting a relatively strong model for generating puns. They focused on generating homophone puns by taking a given sentence and replacing two words, one of which was the pun/homophone, and the other was to provide context for the pun. Their results were pretty good, and definitely really encouraging in demonstrating how powerful NLP methods can be.
Moving forward, I’m sure that researchers will continue finding new and fun applications for their high-performing algorithms!

Extra fun stuff (list of puns from the paper). [Model] indicates that the authors explicitly mentioned that the pun was generated by the model. [Human] indicates that the authors explicitly mentioned that the pun was generated by a human. Otherwise, I’m unsure if it’s a model-generated pun or human-generated pun.
Yesterday I accidentally swallowed some food coloring. The doctor says I’m OK, but I feel like I’ve dyed (died) a little inside.
Old butchers never die, they only meat (meet) their fate.
The negotiator is just a woman trying to peace (piece) her life back together.
Well, gourmet did it, he thought, it’d butter (better) be right. [Model]
Why did the dairy churn? The less said, the butter (better)… [Human]
That’s because negotiator got my car back to me in one peace (piece). [Model]
Life is a puzzle; look here for the missing peace (piece). [Human]
Butter want to know who these two girls are, the new members of the holy flour (flower). [Model]
Betty crocker was a flour (flower) child. [Human]
Even from the outside, I could tell that he’d already lost some wait (weight). [Model]
Patience is a virtue heavy in wait (weight). [Human]
